body: Can you please file a JIRA, and change the title of this PR per the policy?

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/13261767/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/13261767)

Coverage decreased (-0.02%) to 69.483% when pulling **522e6c188809327f098b84dbd7ee07e1dad4a376 on XuMingmin:BEAM-2954** into **50532f0a92d7ce8dbbdc6c3179ab7b9efde6a746 on apache:master**.

The shading config looks like it should work.

However, we need to make sure we can include the classes from these artifacts as part of our distribution, based on their license.

Calcite is Apache License 2.0 so should be fine
Janino is BSD license https://raw.githubusercontent.com/janino-compiler/janino/master/LICENSE

@davorbonaci

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/13262452/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/13262452)

Coverage decreased (-0.2%) to 69.509% when pulling **2c98ab8c450afd1065eb9da09a3d9a262090322b on robertwb:pvalueish** into **e9d3a4a799a43a3a9d73527d83ead143b7a66fda on apache:master**.

Thanks @aviemzur.

Some licensing comments:
- Anything that is included in our jar should be relocated, so there's no classpath collision if some other dependency uses the same thing. On the high level, our jars shouldn't include any classes outside `org.apache.beam.<component>`, because everything is relocated.
- There should be a corresponding `SurfaceTest` to make sure we are not relocating something that is on the API surface, hence making it impossible to relocate (this may already exist -- didn't check).
- Janino copyright notice should to be copied into our NOTICE with text "Parts of the software are licensed as" phrasing. Calcite is probably fine, unless they have something transitive that may need to be included as well. See documentation on the www.apache.org for exact requirements.

Happy to help -- let me know if you need something else.

This PR is to remove the `setDefaultPipelineOptions` in SerializablePipelineOptions.readObject, is it? (BEAM-2712)

BEAM-2948 bug is because the previous use of the SerializedPipelineOptions, which call ` FileSystems.setDefaultPipelineOptions` in getPipelineOptions. But getPipelineOptions is called in `DoFnOperator.open` (`DoFnOperator.open` is called after `DoFnOperator.initializeState`)

Do I understand correctly?

LGTM. Good call.

Note that most people automatically have the standard template and keep it part of the review.
See #3856 as an example.

We also took on the convention of asking for a specific reviewer with
"R: @username" and to bring attention to this PR for a specific user with "CC: @username"
This convention has not been codified within the contribution guide and would be useful to add there if you don't mind.

Yeah, I too have been swamped by some other stuff, and agreed that these are the kinds of changes that grow stale quickly. I'll try hunting around for another reviewer if I can't get to it right away (and of course will be happy if anyone else just jumps in :)).
It's not immediately clear what "active transitions" means. Is this, essentially trying to get a handle on the overhead of the state sampler itself?

R: @kennknowles
PTAL

Closing this for now since the implementation does not work. I have another one, that is simpler but also doesn't work because there is currently no way of getting around the fact that Flink will shutdown the timer service before calling `close()` on an operator. Meaning that there is no way of blocking on "in-flight" timers. I'll try and get such a feature in Flink, only then can we fix this issue.
Thanks, PTAL.
Retest this please
Thanks, I think you missed my question above regarding the commit titled "Support multiple materializations of the smae pvalue."?
Luke is on vacation, so R: @tgroh

Sorry, I added comments but did not address it directly. The cache is solely an implementation detail that is thrown away as soon as the pipeline is gc'd (and, hopefully, will simply go away completely when we clean things up). In particular, the ref-counting is only used during pipeline execution.

I'm particularly concerned that the issues in the API provided by this PR will be impossible to fix without backward-incompatible changes. We should at least mark this `@Experimental` before 2.2, so that we'll be able to fix it after 2.2 goes out.
Can you be more specific ? Which issues are you referring to which would require the backward-incompatible changes ?
Never mind, see your comments above, let me have a look tomorrow
By the way, I don't think I got any notifications, hence missed the latest comments, thanks

Yup, github's notifications can behave weird. Thanks for looking! Once again, this is definitely a valuable contribution, just let's make the API and implementation cleaner. It might even turn out that with FileIO.readMatches() the best API for this IO is to have no IO at all and just let people apply Tika themselves to the ReadableFile - let's look in more detail in a follow-up PR; this may benefit from some discussion on the mailing list also.

Sure, let me reply to some of your comments first, and then I'll start addressing some of them with PRs.
FYI, I already opened https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/3835 to address some doc typos, thanks

OK, after reading your replies, let me reiterate my two biggest concerns at a high level.

**Typing of the transform result.** Currently the IO returns a PCollection of all Tika-detected content, extracted from all documents, without any ordering between documents or within a document, and without association to the document either. Perhaps I'm unfamiliar with typical use cases of Tika, but I'd assume that the order of content in a document often matters, and when you're reading many documents (e.g. a few thousand PDFs), it matters which document the data came from. Is this usually not the case? (it is usually _not_ the case for the kind of stuff people parse with TextIO - log files, CSV files and alike - that's why such an API is acceptable for TextIO)

**The "non-blocking" thing.** I still do not understand exactly what you're trying to accomplish by having two threads where one waits for the other to do all the work, instead of having one thread that does all the work. The amount of work done is the same either way, right? - you still need to read and parse all the files.

Are you, perhaps, assuming that a runner will wait for a ParDo's `@ProcessElement` call (or a whole bundle) to complete before applying downstream ParDo's to results of the current call (and are you assuming that this is not the case for a `BoundedSource`?) This doesn't have to be the case, e.g. it's definitely not the case in the Dataflow runner: `c.output(element)` under the hood will recursively apply downstream ParDos until a GroupByKey (see fusion https://cloud.google.com/dataflow/service/dataflow-service-desc#fusion-optimization). 

Alternatively: Do you have experiments that show that your implementation provides a substantial performance improvement over the simple ParDo-based implementation?
Run Dataflow ValidatesRunner

Hi, 
re the **typing of the transform result**: 
I think it is just the way I was writing the test, I was not sure how large or small the chunks reported by PDF/ODT parsers would be, so I was updating the test values bit by bit after the test failures till I got the test passing, you can see from the code that the chunks are added to the tail of the internal queue by the Tika content handler and collected from the start of the queue by the reader, the ordering of the data is maintained. 

re **the non-blocking thing**: 
yes, I was thinking yesterday, and in a way it is probably nearly the same (I was not assuming the ParDo would block till the whole file gets parsed). My thinking was, that decoupling the pipeline read from the actual parsing of the content would make the data chunks available faster to the pipeline (not yet backed up by the runs against the massive set of files - I just wanted to make this feature avail to the Tika and Beam communities - and then make it totally right).
The other useful thing with the current approach is that one can try to optimize around the size of the data chunks, for ex, given "A feature" text fragment, one parser may report it as a sequence of "A" and "feature" which might be noisy, so one can try to tune it to make sure only a "A feature" is reported, one of the tests shows it, and it would require ParDo do have its own state to make it work...
Perhaps the right idea would be simply to avoid the polling (to min even the theoretical risk of losing the data) and simply block on the blocking queue - I believe Beam can heal itself if one of the pipelines blocks due to some parser going into some buggy spin, so that might be a good short-term compromise ? 
Let me send a summary to the dev list (as you suggested earlier), I guess indeed it can be made @Experimental till no concerns are left.

Thanks for this contribution. Please also include a unit test to verify. The unmerged PR #853 had a couple new tests, `testEfficiency()` and `testCorrectness()`, and just needed some slight changes to use JUnit `@Parameters`. See: https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/853/files#r75763207
Motivation?
